Let $n = 10^9 + 1.$  Then we want the smallest $k$ so that
\[\binom{n - 1}{k} < \binom{n}{k - 1}.\]Using the formula for a binomial coefficient, we get
\[\frac{(n - 1)!}{k! (n - k - 1)!} < \frac{n!}{(k - 1)! (n - k + 1)!}.\]Then
\[(n - k + 1)(n - k) < nk.\]We consider the easier inequality $(n - k)^2 < nk.$  Then $n^2 - 2nk + k^2 < nk,$ or $k^2 - 3nk + n^2 < 0.$  By the quadratic formula, the roots of the corresponding equation $k^2 - 3nk + n^2 = 0$ are
\[\frac{3 \pm \sqrt{5}}{2} \cdot n.\]So if $(n - k)^2 < nk,$ we must have $k > \alpha n,$ where $\alpha = \frac{3 - \sqrt{5}}{2}.$  Note that $\alpha^2 - 3 \alpha + 1 = 0.$

If $k < \alpha n$, then
\begin{align*}
(n - k + 1)(n - k) &> (n - k)^2 \\
&> (n - \alpha n)^2 \\
&= (1 - \alpha)^2 n^2 \\
&= (1 - 2 \alpha + \alpha^2) n^2 \\
&= \alpha n^2 \\
&= n (\alpha n) > nk.
\end{align*}On the other hand, if $k > \alpha (n + 1),$ then
\begin{align*}
(n - k + 1)(n - k) &= (n + 1 - \alpha(n + 1))(n - \alpha (n + 1)) \\
&< (n + 1)(1 - \alpha)n(1 - \alpha) \\
&= (1 - 2 \alpha + \alpha^2) n(n + 1) \\
&= \alpha n(n + 1) \\
&< nk.
\end{align*}Therefore, the smallest such $k$ satisfies
\[\alpha n < k < \alpha (n + 1).\]For $n = 10^9 + 1,$ this gives us
\[3819660 \dotsc < n < 3819660 \dots,\]so $a = 3$ and $b = 8,$ and the final answer is $\boxed{38}.$
